title: Set VSA datepicker to correct UTC date
description:
## Background
> I tested this branch locally and when I open this URL in the browser:
> 
> http://localhost:3000/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics?group_id=flightjs&project_ids%5B%5D=6&created_after=2020-01-08&created_before=2020-02-13
> 
> I get the following date range:

![Wrong to date](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/a70adc7f2d420bd1c35be3dda0170a7c/image.png)

* To date should be `2020-02-13`

## Proposed solution
### Date range picker fix

- [x] ~frontend https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97106+

It looks like the shared daterange component for cycle (value stream) analytics and productivity might not take timezones into account. We will need to investigate if this is due to a date being generated from the FE or the BE from a deep link.

- [ ] @ekigbo started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23493#note_282966403):  (+4 comments)

    > Hi @ealcantara are you free to review this MR for me? This MR is based on backend changes in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23235, so i've marked the files that you can ignore reviewing here.

### Support full UTC timestamp
- [ ] ~backend https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/374297+
- [ ] ~frontend https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/374297+

title: Cannot include downstream pipeline with `include:file`
description:
### Summary `include:file` does not work with `trigger` in parent-child pipeline feature This is strange since the [parent-child pipeline docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/parent_child_pipelines.html) stated that all `include` feature will work to compose the configuration. I've tried the workaround to use `include:remote` to include the file I need, but since the file lives in a private repository and it refers to other local sub-templates in that repo, using a remote URL does not work either. Would there be any way to get around this issue? And why does it happen in the first place? ### Steps to reproduce Triggering a child pipeline using `include:file` results in a CI Lint error "include config contains unknown keys: project, ref" Here's the `.gitlab-ci.yml`: ```yaml images_build_multiple: stage: build trigger: strategy: depend include: - project: 'my-group/my-pipeline-library' ref: 'master' file: 'path/to/child-pipeline.yml' ``` ### What is the current *bug* behavior? `project` and `ref` are not recognized as known key words ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? CI Lint should pass ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Proposal The allowed keys for `include` [should contain `project` and `ref`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/fc8e48926c90d3d8bf435278db29befe8a79b200/lib/gitlab/ci/config/entry/include.rb#L13). With Parent-child pipeline we actually enforce the use of ALLOWED_KEYS validation this is why we see this error because of the missing `project` in the ALLOWED_KEYS. The difference between `trigger:include` and top-level `include` is that with the first we [set the `value` explicitly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/fc8e48926c90d3d8bf435278db29befe8a79b200/lib/gitlab/ci/config/entry/trigger.rb#L68) which is used [by the validator](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/48f51b08870834c99f44876c34ecce17b2f3f036/lib/gitlab/config/entry/validators.rb#L9-10).

title: GitLab-Flavored Markdown References should work when there is a trailing slash
description:
```
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24334/
```

Will generate a link with a trailing slash that's not considered part of the reference:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24334/

This becomes a noticeable problem when linking to comments.

```
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24334/#note_284469896
```

Becomes:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24334/#note_284469896

When it should render the same as when there is no trailing slash:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24334#note_284469896

title: Change all the initial importing to push into the sorted sets
description:
Follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/34086

1. Change all the initial importing to push into the sorted sets instead of using the sidekiq queues like we currently have. This can be left out of this issue since it's the incremental updates which causes the queues to grow massively and are generally less efficient due to duplicate updates. We should also see if we can put initial indexing into a separate queue but processed with exactly the same logic. This would allow incremental updates to keep processing and not end up being delayed because they happen after a very large queue forms for newly added groups. This could be an optimization later though.

title: Geo: Continue to make registry table SSOT for LFS objects
description:
The following discussion from !20002 should be addressed:

- [ ] @dbalexandre started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/20002#note_286425245):  (+2 comments)

    > Should we change this method to not rely on FDW too?

`LfsObjectRegistryFinder` has a bunch of methods that still use FDW. If the feature flag `:geo_lfs_registry_ssot_sync` is enabled, let's make more things treat the registry table as SSOT (don't do a cross-database join, instead just query the registry table).

### Caveats

- This issue depends on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/204797 since we must ensure registries are removed if they should not be synced.
- We might want to leave counts alone for now, since we don't have create events. If we don't have create events, then anything treating the registry as SSOT can be up to 2 minutes out-of-date for new items.

title: Remove N+1 query in Vulnerabilities::OccurrencePreloader
description:
# Summary

`Vulnerabilities::FindingsPreloader` creates an N+1 query for loading `vulnerability_identifiers`.

## Links

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24757#note_285086858

## Steps to reproduce

1. Visit `/-/security/vulnerability_findings.json` path
2. Check the development logs to see N+1 queries which load `vulnerability_identifiers`.

## Technical Notes

For some reason(See [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/205095#note_366565039)), the `Occurrence#first_fingerprint` method is getting called which is loading the `identifiers` for each occurrence.

The solution would be, using the BatchLoader to load all the first `vulnerability_identifiers` for each occurrence. An example SQL query to load records from database would be similar to this;

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT ON (voi.occurrence_id) vi.*
FROM vulnerability_identifiers vi
INNER JOIN vulnerability_occurrence_identifiers voi ON voi.identifier_id = vi.id
WHERE voi.occurrence_id IN (?)
ORDER BY voi.occurrence_id, vi.id ASC;
```

where the parameter is IDs of occurrences. You can check `Occurrence#load_feedback` method to see an example usage of `BatchLoader`.

title: Add CLI options for gemnasium-maven when scanning gradle and sbt projects
description:
### Problem to solve

`gemnasium-maven` doesn't allow users to specify cli options when scanning gradle and sbt repositories. This prevents users from doing things like dependency scanning projects which have private repos because there is no way to specify login credentials for these repos. 

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### Proposal

Add new analyzer variables which will let users specify cli options for gradle and sbt.

### Implementation plan

- [ ] add `GRADLE_CLI_OPTS` and `SBT_CLI_OPTS` to `gemnasium-maven` which are passed to their respective dependency scanning commands
- [ ] create branches in test projects to use these vars
- [ ] update the dependency scanning [template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/raw/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml) to use the new vars

### Documentation

- [ ] add an entry to the [dependency scanning documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/index.html) for these variables with an explanation on how to use them.

### Availability & Testing

- [ ] update the [java-gradle test project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/java-gradle/) with a branch requiring project variables to build/install dependencies (e.g. a dependency version that comes from a cli variable) and ensure that the new functionality passes
- [ ] update the [scala-sbt test project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/scala-sbt/) with a branch requiring project variables to build/install dependencies (e.g. a dependency version that comes from a cli variable) and ensure that the new functionality passes

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

- [ ] we can run `gemnasium-maven` against a {gradle,sbt} project that requires project properties to fetch dependencies

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Links / references
